instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00164: What is 820-00164? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.P5VS0_EN: What is P5VS0_EN? This signal enables the PP5V_S0 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.5V_S0: What is 5V_S0? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S0”.
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.EDP_BKLT_EN: What is EDP_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “EDP_BKLT” which stands for “embedded displayport backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .
definitions.Q7706: What is Q7706? Q7706 takes PPBUS_G3H's main 12.6v and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q7706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R7788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q7706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.820-3453: What is 820-3453? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: Macbook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Need <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>
threads.message:
Hello,

New to the forum, so glad to be part of it! I have much experience with electronics but not as much with MBs though I have experience there too. This is my first time working with a shop that will hire me if I can prove I can fix boards for them.

I have gotten a macbook air with no power but green and orange light. No power but does charge. The board makes it to S0 state. <SIGNAL>PPV3V3_S0</SIGNAL> is present but <SIGNAL>PPV5V_S0</SIGNAL> is not. I found that the enable signal to <CHIP>U8080</CHIP> was not present. I then found that resistor <RESISTOR>R8187</RESISTOR> which is more a jumper was open. This jumper takes the <SIGNAL>P5VS0_EN</SIGNAL> signal from <CHIP>U8180</CHIP> and sends it over to <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>. <CHIP>U8180</CHIP> does have all the right voltages including the outgoing engage signal for <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>. I jumpered <RESISTOR>R8187</RESISTOR> and found that engage signal still does not make it and it even goes missing at <CHIP>U8180</CHIP> now too. If I measure the incoming voltages to <CHIP>U8180</CHIP>, the VCC voltage is still there but <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> begins to "blink" as if is being overwhelmed and protecting itself. <CHIP>U8080</CHIP> does also have it's VDD. It's as if <CHIP>U8080</CHIP> engage pin is shorted to groun and when I reconnect <CHIP>U8180</CHIP> it messes it up too. Also after this test it seemed like <CHIP>U8080</CHIP> was hot. <CHIP>U8080</CHIP> doesn't measure low to ground on output, VDD,  or engage pin. I believe the IC might just be dead. Is my diagnosis correct you think?

I see the IC is for sale from china but would take a long time to get here.

Does anyone have this IC on hand who can sell it to me? Even if it's from a dead board. SLG5AP1443V is the part number. Cannot find datasheet.

Thanks!

threads.title: Macbook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Need <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>
threads.message:
You have a problem on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> power rail.
This is the reason <CHIP>U8080</CHIP> gets hot and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> also pulses.
Just for test, <CHIP>U8080</CHIP> can be shorted I/O (3-5).
If you don't have short/low value to ground on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> is not easy to find the problem; post the value however.
I recommend to remove <CHIP>U8080</CHIP> first and try bypassing it (as above mentioned); just to discard it.

threads.title: Macbook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Need <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>
threads.message: Okay thanks let me give that a shot.

threads.title: Macbook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Need <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>
threads.message:
Looks like youre right, i get the same pulsing after hooking those two lines up. This time im seeing a resistance between <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> and GND. 63K Ohm when black is on ground, 32Kohm when red is on ground. This is still high for a 5V line. It would be great if someone with a working board could give me their reading. I did notice <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> getting kinda warm when this thing was plugged in. Not very warm but noticeably warm, kinda the only warm thing on the board. Besides this I have almost no other clues, everything else is squeaky clean. No oxidation.

I guess I can start by looking at all the sub rails that depend on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>

threads.title: Macbook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Need <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>
threads.message: So how much of a bad idea would it be if I just forced 5V into this missing rail and watch for smoke or heat? I plan on hooking a usb charger up to it and limiting the current with an incandescent bulb.

threads.title: Macbook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Need <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>
threads.message:
As you don't have a short, nor even low value, probably nothing heats.
Unless you are lucky and the culprit enters in some kind of avalanche process.

Do you get a pulse on all big coils?
Did you try to start in SMC bypass mode?

threads.title: Macbook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Need <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>
threads.message:
What I'm wondering is if maybe one of the buck or boost circuits that feeds from <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> is the one with a short on it's output. I snooped around a but so far nothing has happened. My theory was that if a dependent buck converter was drawing excessive current, or perhaps any other circuit where IT'S output has a short, it would cause <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> to draw excessive current and it be commanded to stay off. If the short was on the output of a dependent circuit this would also mask the short when measuring <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>. Does that sound plausible?

I am not aware as to how to perform SMC bypass. Can you please explain? A google search brings up mostly SMC reset results, which i did.

EDIT: As for big coils, which ones do you mean?  The ones that give the CPU power?

threads.title: Macbook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Need <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>
threads.message:
You should check all coils.
If one coil no voltage, nor pulse at all, look if is powered from <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: Macbook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Need <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>
threads.message: Thank you, I'll give that a try.  Will report later.

threads.title: Macbook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Need <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>
threads.message:
Okay i measured it. L3095 and L7701 are the only two coils that don't tick. All other coils peak at around .52 or so then go off. L7520 peaks at around 1.8v then disables. L7560 is makiing 3.3V. L7130 is making 8.5V. Neither of the coils that do not pulse show low resistance to ground. LL7701 is backlight boost and L3095 is thunderbolt.

<CHIP>U2800</CHIP> is thunder host which is the part I notice is warm when I leave this thing plugged in. Is this normal? Possible lead? The thing is neither of the respective chips for L3095 or L7701 are receiving their enable signals.

<TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR> gets voltage in but none out. This is what sends voltage to L7701. <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> enable signal too.
<TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR> gets 8.1 voltage at gate. This turns it off. <TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR> has to pull down <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR> gate but this doesn't occurr.
<TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR> needs signals <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>BKLT_PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL> which do not arrive. Both have origins in the PCH though the second one goes through a logic gate first, which is getting one of it's signals. It's an AND gate. PCH is not telling this to turn on.

<TRANSISTOR>Q3080</TRANSISTOR> gets voltage in but none out. This is what sends voltage to <CHIP>U3090</CHIP> vin and L3095.
<TRANSISTOR>Q3080</TRANSISTOR> postive 8.5 at gate which turns it off.
<TRANSISTOR>Q3080</TRANSISTOR> has to be turned on by <TRANSISTOR>Q3005</TRANSISTOR>.
<TRANSISTOR>Q3005</TRANSISTOR> has no positive voltage on <SIGNAL>TBT_A_HV_EN</SIGNAL>. Originating from <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>

This is what I have found so far.

EDIT: I put a 390 ohm between <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> pins instead of a bridge (where <CHIP>U8080</CHIP> was) and even at a theoretical limit of 20mA the 5V PS shuts down. This time no pulsing.

threads.title: Macbook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Need <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>
threads.message:
My latest finding

Figuring that maybe the short isnt on the 5v line and that perhaps the activation of that 5V line is turning on an IC or transistor that shorts out a different unrelated line I cut the incoming 16.5v and put an ammeter there. The board idles at 20mA and when it peaks it hits close to 100mA then goes back down and resettles at 20mA.

I also measured current at <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> again and only about 10mA tries to go in there.

EDIT:

So I made a mistake, the computer is NOT making it into SO state. <SIGNAL>PP3V3_0</SIGNAL> is also doing the same thing.  I confused it with <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: Macbook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Need <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>
threads.message:
Which is the history of this fault?
Any liquid sign?

threads.title: Macbook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Need <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>
threads.message:
I got fan spin!!!! I removed the enable signal to <CHIP>U8030</CHIP>. It's going to be a bitch figuring out why that helped though. No ground on this rail. This creates <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>

No liquid spill. Not sure what the history is. Looks spotless.

threads.title: Macbook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Need <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>
threads.message:
Do you got all voltages now?
Looks like a problem on <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL>.
Check connections between R/<CHIP>U5440</CHIP>.
Does it work in SMC bypass mode (with <CHIP>U8030</CHIP> enabled)?

threads.title: Macbook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Need <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>
threads.message:
Im getting all coil voltages except L7701, L3095, L2920, L7310, and L7320.

I don't know how to do SMC bypass. Please explain?

These last two produce <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> 1 and 2. These two i mentioned before as reading 13 ohms to ground. I took out one of the current sense resistors and on CPU side it measures about 8 ohms. Coil side reads normal. CPUs tend to read low but is that too much?

SO to summarize, for some reason <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> being on, makes <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> trip out and shut down, at the same time the enable signal shuts down for <CHIP>U8080</CHIP> and <CHIP>U8030</CHIP> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>, and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> shut down while <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> keeps going fine.

If I disable <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> then <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4S3</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> both stay on as does <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and a whole lot of rails come to life. Likewise if I keep <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4S3</SIGNAL> disconnected from <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> it and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> both exist happily side by side.

Im gonna guess that whatever causes the issue is on the 5V line, not sure on what step though. 3V S0 is tripping something on the 5v line to over consume. We know that it isnt 5V S0.. but perhaps S4, S3 etc.

threads.title: Macbook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Need <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>
threads.message:
My updates for today.

I figured out what i think is the SMC bypass routine. Put everything back together and connected the magsafe charger while holding down the power button for a while. Nothing happened.

Tried SMC reset too, with and without charger connected. With the charger i can see the amber light go back to green for a moment.

Went around analyzing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>. This voltage dips and ticks if <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> is around at the same time. It is created by <TRANSISTOR>Q7520</TRANSISTOR> and <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> both of which feed from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_GH3</SIGNAL>. This rails flickers a bit when the fault occurs but only goes down by about 0.2 or 0.3 volts. So the fault is definitely on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> or its associated components. This same IC creates <SIGNAL>PP3V_S5</SIGNAL> through <TRANSISTOR>Q7560</TRANSISTOR>, this rail is working fine.

I went looking for things that could cause a new load on our <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> when <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> is activated and found:

<CHIP>U7600</CHIP> untested other than for shots.
<CHIP>U8080</CHIP> which we know works fine as long as <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> isn't on so no short or issue here as far as i can tell. All of <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> is clear as it works while <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> is not available.
L4011, not on this board.
<CHIP>U4600</CHIP> USB port power. I looked for shorts, none and also to make sure there was no pin throwing a fault. This pin is high 3,3V which means its okay as its active low. If im not mistaken.
<CHIP>U6410</CHIP> speaker IC. Removed a jumper to isolate it, did not help.

There are some more things but this is what i looked into.

The only other main place I can see is the DC in/Audio board I actually did find a bit of corrosion here, it's light but there. Hiding under the ribbon cable that connects this board logic to the main. I found that the codec IC has several resistors that read ground on both sides. These resistors were removed and the ground was only on one side. However all these resistors are all only 0 ohm resistors so perhaps this is how they are. Removing them did not fix the issue but perhaps there is a short inside the IC? Why there would be these external connections to ground for the IC?

If anyone had me that could confirm that would be great, it's my only real clue right now. The board is APN 923-0430 aka <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3453</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A. I see a thread here with some also describing problems with <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>. Would hate to buy this board only to find it's not the issue. [URL="https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/forum/board-repair-troubleshooting/29660-<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-no-power-weird-behavior-on-ppbus-g3h"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/for...r-on-ppbus-g3h

Audio Codec is a CIRRUS 4208-CRZ. Found chip info but not much help.

NVM about the Codec, those were inductors to ground.[/URL]

threads.title: Macbook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Need <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>
threads.message:
Disconnect LIO flex, keep only 5 pins DC cable connected.
Board should start automatically when charger is connected.

You don't have a problem directly on 3V3/<SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> lines.
I suppose some chip is enabled when <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL> appears and then generates overcurrent on <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL>, or <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL> rail...

threads.title: Macbook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Need <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>
threads.message: Tried that but no luck. Shows same amount of current consumption and everything.

threads.title: Macbook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Need <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>
threads.message: Did you resolder <CHIP>U8030</CHIP>/80 as in original state?

threads.title: Macbook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Need <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>
threads.message:
Yes I did.

I have managed to inch closer to the fault. When I ground the enable pin to <CHIP>U8005</CHIP> 1.05V PCH HSIO Switch all the rails turn on, including some of the ones that didnt turn on before like L7310 and L7320 which are making 1.05V volts.

The offending line seems to be <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0SW_PCH_HSIO</SIGNAL>. Concerning me is the fact that some of theses connections go to the PCH. Many of them in fact. Any clues? Onward....

There is no shorts on it's output or input. Need to see if this is enable on high or enable on low.

EDIT: Okay so turning it OFF brings everything else back online.

threads.title: Macbook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Need <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>
threads.message:
Change <CHIP>U8005</CHIP>, to discard it as culprite.
You can also try to remove it and make short D-S...

threads.title: Macbook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Need <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>
threads.message: Thought I had replied already.  I removed and bridged <CHIP>U8005</CHIP>.  Fault persisted.  The only thing that solved it was disconnecting L1290.  L1295 is omitteed.  Tried removing the coupling caps.  It looks to me like the PCH is bad as that is all that is left connecting here.

threads.title: Macbook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Need <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>
threads.message: In this case, nothing more to do, sorry...

threads.title: Macbook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Need <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>
threads.message: I figured.  Im happy i could narrow it down to the fault though.  This is what mattered to me most.  Thanks for all the help!

threads.title: Macbook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Need <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>
threads.message:
I know it's old, but if anyone else searches for that part, it is (currently) at aliexpress a ton cheaper than on ebay...:

[URL unfurl="true"]https://www.aliexpress.com/item/1005003442131314.html[/URL]
